G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters relating to the custody, care, and support of the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, §§ 10, 20 (as applicable); G.L. c. 215, § 6; and the prior Judgment of this Court dated May 15, 2018.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7\u00a7 10, 20 (as ap.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters relating to the custody, care, and support of the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, §§ 10, 20 (as applicable); G.L. c. 215, § 6; and the prior Judgment of this Court dated May 15, 2018.

G.L. c. 215, \u00a7 6.proposition: This Court has continuing jurisdiction over matters relating to the custody, care, and support of the minor child pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28; G.L. c. 209C, §§ 10, 20 (as applicable); G.L. c. 215, § 6; and the prior Judgment of this Court dated May 15, 2018.

G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 31.proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody or parenting-time order where (1) there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 10(a).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody or parenting-time order where (1) there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody or parenting-time order where (1) there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion concerns a removal/relocation dispute under G.L. c. 208, § 30 in a joint custody context and applies a pure ‘best interests of the child’ standard to decide whether to authorize removal. It does not discuss the general standard for modifying custody or parenting-time orders, and it does not articulate or apply a ‘material and substantial change in circumstances’ requirement as a predicate to modification. Thus, it does not provide authority for the two-part modification test described in the proposition.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 30, provides that ‘[a] minor child of divorced parents…shall not … be removed out of this [C]ommonwealth … without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.’ ‘The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child.’ Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 711 (1985)… Assuming the judge’s findings are not clearly erroneous, we review her determination of the best interests of the children only for an abuse of discretion.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody or parenting-time order where (1) there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The case does not involve or decide a modification of an existing custody or parenting-time judgment. Instead, the SJC explicitly declines to apply or analyze the G.L. c. 209C, § 20 ‘substantial change in circumstances’ modification standard, holding that the case was tried as an initial custody determination under § 10(a), governed by the best interests standard. Because the opinion treats the ‘substantial change’ rule only in passing and expressly refuses to reach that issue, it does not supply authority for when a Probate and Family Court may modify a prior order.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “We also decline to consider the father’s claim that the probate judge should have applied the ‘substantial change in the circumstances’ standard applicable to modification actions brought under G. L. c. 209C, § 20, rather than the ‘best interests of the child’ standard applicable to custody determinations under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a). … It is clear from the record that the case in the Probate Court was tried under G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), not G. L. c. 209C, § 20…”

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).proposition: Under Massachusetts law, a Probate and Family Court may modify a prior custody or parenting-time order where (1) there has been a material and substantial change in circumstances since the entry of the prior judgment, and (2) modification is necessary in the best interests of the child.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).support_reasoning: The opinion in Custody of Vaughn concerns standards for custody determinations and, in particular, the requirement that Probate and Family Court judges make explicit findings regarding domestic violence and its effect on the child when awarding or continuing custody. It does not discuss the standard for *modifying* a prior custody or parenting-time order, nor does it articulate the "material and substantial change in circumstances" test for modification. The case addresses best-interest and domestic-violence findings in an initial/supplemental custody judgment, not the threshold for modification of an existing judgment.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. 590 (1996).relevant_excerpt: "Domestic violence is an issue too fundamental and frequently recurring to be dealt with only by implication. ... Requiring the courts to make explicit findings about the effect of the violence on the child and the appropriateness of the custody award in light of that effect will serve to keep these matters well in the foreground of the judges’ thinking. ... Accordingly, we remand the case to the Probate Court for such explicit findings, both as we require in this decision and as we state are required by G. L. c. 208, § 31."

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Mother’s increased availability and stability constitute a material change from the circumstances the Court considered in 2018 when limiting her parenting time.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a later (2018) change‑of‑custody context and claims that a mother’s increased availability and stability constitute a material change from earlier circumstances. Rosenthal v. Maney does not involve any 2018 order nor treat increased availability/stability as a ‘material change’; in fact, the court holds that the mother’s improved schedule and increased time with the child did not warrant a change in custody and that there was no post‑divorce change sufficient to justify modifying custody. The case therefore does not support the asserted proposition and, if anything, cuts against it.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “Second, by the time of trial, the probate judge found that positive changes in the mother’s work schedule ‘allowed her to spend more time with the minor child. For example, she began to drive Caleb to school in the mornings and became a volunteer classroom parent.’ Thus, to the extent that changes in the mother’s work schedule did occur, they were not changes warranting a modification in the custody arrangement. … There is nothing in the findings or the record before us to indicate that anything occurred after the divorce that so altered the circumstances of the parties as to warrant a change in custodial arrangements …”

Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.raw_text: Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 734 (1996)
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.proposition: Mother’s increased availability and stability constitute a material change from the circumstances the Court considered in 2018 when limiting her parenting time.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.support_reasoning: The case does discuss a material and substantial change in circumstances justifying modification of custody, but the change found here is the mother’s success in overcoming alcohol and drug dependence, not a more general concept of her increased availability and stability compared to an earlier order. The opinion is focused on (1) whether the mother’s rehabilitation is a material change under G.L. c. 208, § 28, and (2) whether splitting twins is in their best interests; it does not establish any principle about a later court using the mother’s increased availability and stability, relative to a 2018 order, as a material change. Thus it does not support the specific proposition claimed.
Ardizoni v. Raymond, 40 Mass. App. Ct. 7.relevant_excerpt: “In allowing the wife’s complaint for modification, the judge cited as a material and substantial change in circumstances, the wife’s ‘great success in overcoming her alcohol and drug dependence.’ … [T]he wife’s progress in this regard, since the divorce decree granting temporary physical custody of the twins to the father, was supported by evidence in the record. Hence, the finding that a material and substantial change in circumstances had occurred was not clearly erroneous.”

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: Mother’s improved housing — both in size and suitability for the child — is a significant and material change from the circumstances underlying the prior order, warranting reconsideration of the parenting schedule.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: The opinion concerns an initial divorce judgment awarding physical custody to the mother and permitting her to relocate the children to Greece under the ‘real advantage’ removal standard. It does not address any post-judgment modification based on a change in housing circumstances, nor does it discuss improved housing size or suitability as a material change warranting reconsideration of a parenting schedule. The case is about relocation and best interests, not about modification due to improved housing conditions.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: “Cases involving removal of a child from the jurisdiction present difficult choices… An evaluation of the best interests of the child requires attention to whether the quality of the child’s life may be improved by the change (including any improvement flowing from an improvement in the quality of the custodial parent’s life)… The interest of the custodial parent in moving must also be assessed. The relative advantages to the custodial parent from the move… are all likely to be relevant considerations.”

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 231\t6.proposition: Massachusetts law recognizes that as children grow older, their preferences and developmental needs may become more relevant to the best-interests analysis.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 231\t6.support_reasoning: The opinion repeatedly applies and discusses the general "best interests of the child" standard, including stability, sibling relationships, and developmental needs, but it does not specifically address how a child’s own preferences, or the increasing relevance of those preferences and developmental needs as the child grows older, factor into that analysis. Hugo was very young (about four), and the court focuses on expert testimony and comparative capacities of caregivers, not on the evolving weight of an older child’s views or age-related developmental autonomy. Thus, it does not clearly stand for the proposition about older children’s preferences becoming more relevant over time.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. 219, 231\t6.relevant_excerpt: "Here, the judge had to weigh the benefits of stability, of keeping Hugo in his present home, with moving him to a family where, in his judgment, it is more likely that Hugo will receive the home support, stability, and reinforcement of efforts to address his developmental needs so critical to his future development."

Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 231\t6.proposition: While a minor child’s preference is not determinative, Massachusetts courts recognize that the child’s expressed wishes, particularly those of a mature child, are one factor to be weighed in assessing best interests.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 231\t6.support_reasoning: The opinion excerpt deals extensively with best interests, stability, sibling relationships, expert testimony, and the weighing of competing adoption plans, but it does not discuss a minor child’s own expressed custodial preference at all. Hugo is four years old and there is no mention of his wishes, nor any broader statement about how Massachusetts courts consider the preferences of mature children. Accordingly, this case does not provide authority for the proposition concerning consideration of a child’s stated preference.
Adoption of Hugo, 428 Mass. at 231\t6.relevant_excerpt: We recognize that separating Hugo from his foster family will have negative consequences for him, although the experts disagree as to the long-term effects of those consequences. While judgments in these cases are immensely difficult, we cannot say that avoiding the trauma of separation had to be the determining factor for the judge. ... In some cases, the importance of leaving a child in the home of his substitute caretaker may be the most important determining factor. In others, there may be evidence that pulls in a different direction.

Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 599.proposition: While a minor child’s preference is not determinative, Massachusetts courts recognize that the child’s expressed wishes, particularly those of a mature child, are one factor to be weighed in assessing best interests.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 599.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly states that the child’s preference, here that of an eleven-year-old, is not given decisive (determinative) weight but is a factor to be considered, and it cites other Massachusetts authorities for that principle. The court also acknowledges the child’s clearly stated affection and preference, indicating it is one factor in the best-interests analysis, especially as the child matures (here noting he is now almost fourteen). This directly aligns with the claimed proposition.
Custody of Vaughn, 422 Mass. at 599.relevant_excerpt: “Although the boy was described in testimony as ‘a really bright student,’ we note that the preference of an eleven-year-old is not given decisive weight, although it is a factor to be considered. See Custody of a Minor, 383 Mass. 595, 602 (1981); Baird v. Attorney Gen., 371 Mass. 741, 753 (1977); Bellotti v. Baird, 443 U.S. 622 (1979); Stone v. Duffy, 219 Mass. 178, 182 (1914); Bak v. Bak, 24 Mass. App. Ct. 608, 617 (1987). … As almost three years have gone by … it may be appropriate for the judge to interview the child again as to his preference….”

Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..raw_text: Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899 (1981) (rescript)
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..proposition: This pattern of resistance to reasonable modification in light of changed circumstances supports the need for Court intervention to adjust the schedule in Emily’s best interests.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..support_reasoning: The opinion focuses on the legal standard for awarding custody—emphasizing that all relevant factors must be weighed and that the child’s welfare is paramount. It does not discuss a parent’s resistance to modifying an existing schedule, changed circumstances, or the need for court intervention to adjust parenting time. Therefore, it does not provide authority for the specific proposition about resistance to reasonable modification justifying court intervention.
Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct..relevant_excerpt: “In a proceeding involving custody of a child, ‘as matter of law and as matter of humanity’ ‘[t]he governing principle by which the court must be guided in deciding the issues raised is the welfare of the child’… This court will not sustain a custody award unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed. The weight ascribed to the respective factors is to be measured solely in terms of its effect on the welfare or well being of the child.”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 404	6 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.proposition: This pattern of resistance to reasonable modification in light of changed circumstances supports the need for Court intervention to adjust the schedule in Emily’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.support_reasoning: The proposition concerns a ‘pattern of resistance to reasonable modification in light of changed circumstances’ justifying court intervention to adjust a parenting schedule. Rolde v. Rolde is an appeal from an original divorce judgment, addressing initial custody, visitation, and property division—not post‑judgment modification, changed circumstances, or a parent’s resistance to modifying an existing schedule. While the opinion discusses best interests and limiting visitation, it does not frame this in terms of a party’s resistance to reasonable modification, so it does not provide authority for the specific proposition stated.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398, 4.relevant_excerpt: “From our above discussion of the record, it should be readily apparent that in view of the circumstances and the personalities involved the judge was justified in reducing the husband’s visitation to less than it previously had been under the temporary custody order. … ‘[T]he ‘best interests’ of the child[ren] are to be promoted, and when the parents are at odds [as here], the attainment of that purpose may involve some limitation of the liberties of one or other of the parents.’ Felton v. Felton, supra at 233.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 840\t641.support_reasoning: The opinion discusses the "best interests of the child" standard in depth, but in this excerpt it does not set out or adopt a specific multi-factor list like the one in the proposition (age/development, emotional ties, parental capacities, willingness to foster relationship with the other parent, environmental stability/continued contact). Instead, it emphasizes statutory factors under G.L. c. 209C, § 10(a) (primary caregiver, recent residence, parental relationship/responsibility) and the importance of stability and continuity. Thus, while it is generally consistent with a broad best-interests analysis, it is not authority for the particular enumerated factors claimed.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. at 840\t641.relevant_excerpt: “However, we will not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’ Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182, 191 (1998), quoting Bouchard v. Bouchard, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 899, 899 (1981). … The required considerations of the second paragraph of G. L. c. 209C, § 10 (a), neither replace the ‘best interests of the child’ standard nor limit the factors that a judge may consider in determining what custodial arrangements are in the best interests of the child.”}

Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.support_reasoning: Rosenberg v. Merida concerns (1) whether Social Security disability dependency benefits should be credited against a child support obligation, (2) attachment of assets to secure support/college expenses, and (3) the sufficiency of findings to modify legal custody. While it briefly references the statutory ‘best interests’ standard and the need to weigh ‘all relevant factors,’ it does not articulate or apply the specific, multifactor best‑interests test listed in the proposition (age, ties, parental capacity, willingness to foster relationship, stability). Thus it does not provide authority for that detailed formulation.
Rosenberg v. Merida, 428 Mass. 182 (1998.relevant_excerpt: “General Laws c. 208, § 28, provides that a Probate and Family Court judge may modify an earlier divorce judgment concerning the custody of a minor child on finding ‘that a material and substantial change in the circumstances of the parties has occurred and the judgment of modification is necessary in the best interests of the child[].’… However, we shall not sustain an award of custody ‘unless all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child have been weighed.’”

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: Massachusetts public policy strongly favors arrangements that maintain and encourage a child’s ongoing relationships with both parents, whenever consistent with the child’s best interests.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion explicitly endorses the idea that children are entitled to the love and companionship of both parents and cites with approval the principle that the law values frequent and continuing contact with both parents, subject to the best-interests standard. Although the court ultimately reduces the father’s visitation based on the specific facts, its doctrinal discussion clearly recognizes a policy preference for ongoing relationships with both parents when consistent with the children’s welfare.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “The husband does argue, however, that it is most often preferred that both parents participate in the child rearing process and in the major decisions that attach thereto. We agree with the precept that ‘the law sees a value in “frequent and continuing contact” of the child[ren] with both . . . parents.’ … Children are entitled to the love, companionship and concern of both parents, and they usually are better off if the parents can agree to share in the responsibility of their rearing as well as in physical custody.”

G.L. c. 208, \u0000\u0000\u0000\u0000\u0.proposition: Accordingly, under G.L. c. 208, §§ 28, 31, and related case law, the Court should find that a material and substantial change in circumstances has occurred and that modifying the existing custody / parenting-time order is necessary and appropriate for the best interests of Emily Johnson.
